article.title: Search for new phenomena in dijet events using 37 fb$^{-1}$ of $pp$ collision data collected at $\sqrt s=$13 TeV with the ATLAS detector

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 shows the reconstructed dijet mass distribution. What is the purpose of the vertical lines in the figure?
choices: They indicate the range of the sliding-window fit.
They represent the expected signal for a benchmark model.
They highlight the most discrepant interval identified by the BumpHunter algorithm.
They show the mass threshold where the selection is fully efficient.

multiple_choice_question.text: In the lower panel of Figure 1, what does the shaded band represent?
choices: Statistical uncertainty in the data.
Uncertainty in the NLO and electroweak corrections.
Experimental uncertainty in the jet energy scale calibration.
Uncertainty due to the choice of background parameterization.

multiple_choice_question.text: The middle panel of Figure 1 shows the bin-by-bin significances of the data-fit differences. What type of uncertainties are considered in these significance calculations?
choices: Only statistical uncertainties.
Both statistical and systematic uncertainties.
Only systematic uncertainties.
Uncertainties related to MC modeling and statistics.

multiple_choice_question.text: Comparing the two panels of Figure 1, what conclusion can be drawn about the dijet mass distribution?
choices: Significant deviations from the background prediction are observed in both selections.
The observed distribution agrees well with the background prediction in both selections.
The |y∗| < 1.2 selection shows a significant deviation, while the |y∗| < 0.6 selection does not.
The |y∗| < 0.6 selection shows a significant deviation, while the |y∗| < 1.2 selection does not.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the variable χ represent in Figure 2?
choices: The invariant mass of the dijet system.
The transverse momentum of the leading jet.
A function of the rapidity difference between the two leading jets.
The rapidity of the boosted center-of-mass frame.

multiple_choice_question.text: The shaded bands in Figure 2 represent uncertainties. Which source of uncertainty is dominant in this analysis?
choices: Statistical uncertainty in the simulated NLO corrections.
Uncertainty due to the choice of PDF sets.
Jet energy scale uncertainty.
Theoretical uncertainties.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 compares the data to the Standard Model prediction and examples of Contact Interaction (CI) signals. What can be inferred from this comparison?
choices: The data show a clear preference for the CI signals over the SM prediction.
The SM prediction provides a good description of the data, while the CI signals are disfavored.
Both the SM prediction and the CI signals are consistent with the data within uncertainties.
Neither the SM prediction nor the CI signals can adequately describe the data.

multiple_choice_question.text: How are the data and the Monte Carlo simulation normalized in each panel of Figure 2?
choices: To the integrated luminosity.
To the total number of events.
To unit integral.
To the peak value.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the function f(z) in Equation (1) describe?
choices: The expected signal for a new resonant state.
The shape of the dijet mass distribution for QCD processes.
The distribution of the rapidity difference between the two leading jets.
The probability density function for the BumpHunter algorithm.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the variable z in Equation (1)?
choices: It represents the transverse momentum of the dijet system.
It is the ratio of the dijet mass to the center-of-mass energy.
It is a parameter controlling the width of a hypothetical signal.
It represents the compositeness scale of a contact interaction.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why is a four-parameter fit function required in this analysis, compared to simpler parameterizations used in previous searches?
choices: The increased integrated luminosity requires a more precise description of the dijet mass distribution.
The inclusion of electroweak effects requires additional parameters in the fit.
The extended dijet mass range requires a more complex functional form.
The presence of a clear signal necessitates a more sophisticated fit.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the advantage of using Equation (1) to describe the background in this analysis?
choices: It allows for the extraction of precise signal parameters.
It avoids the use of simulated collisions and associated uncertainties.
It provides a unique signature for different BSM models.
It enables a direct comparison with theoretical predictions from QCD.

multiple_choice_question.text: What kind of physics does Equation (2) describe?
choices: The production of excited quarks.
The decay of quantum black holes.
The interaction of new mediating particles with quarks.
The formation of hadronic jets in QCD processes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the meaning of the energy scale Λ in Equation (2)?
choices: The mass of the new mediating particle.
The strength of the new interaction.
The compositeness scale of the new physics.
The momentum transfer in the interaction.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the term "contact interaction" refer to in the context of Equation (2)?
choices: An interaction mediated by a particle with a very short range.
A direct interaction between quarks without the exchange of a mediating particle.
An interaction that only occurs at very high energies.
An interaction that modifies the angular distribution of dijet events.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does Equation (2) affect the analysis presented in this article?
choices: It provides a background model for the dijet mass distribution.
It predicts the mass of new particles that could be produced in dijet events.
It introduces a new signal that can be searched for in the angular distribution of dijet events.
It explains the discrepancy between the data and the Standard Model prediction.
